awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Improving Elicited Information
awd_abstract_narration:
False confessions/admissions are problematic not only because of the conviction of the innocent, but also because the guilty elude justice. Research has traditionally tackled this issue by identifying methods that increase the risk of false confession. However, there has recently been a shift towards using psychological theory to enhance methods, with the goal of helping investigators distinguish between guilty and innocent suspects. One such method is the Strategic Use of Evidence (SUE), which involves strategic timing of evidence disclosure (e.g., early vs. late disclosure) and strategic evidence-related questioning to increase statement-evidence inconsistencies in guilty suspects' statements. While SUE has been demonstrated to effectively enhance the difference between liars and truth-tellers, it has yet to be tested using experimental methods rich in psychological realism that better simulate real-world situations (i.e., participants intentionally commit a transgression and are subsequently questioned). In addition, contemporary variations of SUE have yet to be tested with both innocent and guilty suspects. The present research addresses these gaps, and in doing so will: (1) shed light on which SUE variation results in the greatest amount of elicited information; (2) result in findings that are highly applicable to practitioners, as the present experimental methodology better mirrors real-world situations; and (3) offer research experience to underrepresented minority researchers. Overall, the present research will aid law enforcement in obtaining valuable information pertinent to accurately identifying perpetrators and efficiently solving cases. 

To achieve these goals, the present research will employ a cheating paradigm variation in which a research assistant pretending to be a participant prompts (or does not prompt) actual participants to cheat on a supposed "government-issued" test. This enables questioner to accuse both innocent and guilty participants of cheating, and to question them using one of four evidence disclosure methods: Early (presenting evidence before questioning), Late (basic SUE, with evidence presented after all questioning), SUE-C (presenting evidence incrementally, with statement-evidence inconsistencies being pointed out), and SUE-C/E (same as SUE-C, except suspects are required to explain any inconsistencies). Except for the Early condition, all conditions represent variations of the SUE technique. It is predicted that: (1) of all evidence disclosure tactics, SUE-C/E will result in the most diagnostic confessions; (2) all SUE variations will result in more lie indicators (i.e., statement-evidence inconsistencies), as compared to early evidence disclosure; and (3) guilty suspects will ultimately offer more incriminating details when questioned with the SUE variations than with early disclosure. Given that findings fall in line with these predictions, SUE can be advocated to law enforcement investigators as a method to help them enhance their investigations.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project aimed to test the usefulness of the Strategic Use of Evidence (SUE) in the investigative interviewing context. SUE is a science-based method of evidence presentation developed to obtain reliable cues to deception (specifically, suspect statements that are inconsistent with the evidence) via strategic timing of evidence disclosure (gradual/late disclosure vs. early disclosure of evidence) and strategic questioning (questions designed to exhaust potential explanations for the evidence that a suspect might offer).

To test the SUE method, we used a novel psychologically-realistic interrogation paradigm in which community member participants were tempted (or not tempted) to break an experimental rule, ultimately making their own decision whether to break the rule or not. All participants (both those guilty and innocent of rule-breaking) were accused of breaking the rule, and participants believed that they may have had to pay government fines if judged to be guilty. Participants were then questioned using either early evidence disclosure or one of three SUE variations. We found that guilty (vs. innocent) participants were more likely to confess (with guilty participants' feelings of guilt significantly predicting their decision to confess), but that evidence disclosure method did not influence confessions. Furthermore, guilty (vs. innocent) participants were more likely to make statements inconsistent with the evidence. Of particular interest, this was especially so in the three SUE conditions, when the interrogator: presented all the evidence at the end of questioning (Late disclosure); gradually presented the evidence, emphasizing statement-evidence inconsistencies (SUE-Confrontation); or gradually presented the evidence, emphasizing statement-evidence inconsistencies while also giving participants the chance to explain why they were being inconsistent with the evidence (SUE-Confrontation/Explain). In sum, strategic evidence disclosure outperformed the customary practice of confronting suspects with evidence at the start of questioning in terms of obtaining statement-evidence inconsistencies, therein emphasizing the benefits of science-based evidence presentation methods.

We additionally tested the effect of evidence presentation method on laypersons' ability to accurately judge interviewees' culpability. To accomplish this, we recruited community members to watch two interrogation videos that had been recorded during Study 1 (one guilty interviewee and one innocent) wherein the interrogator used early evidence disclosure or one of the three SUE techniques. Our findings indicate that laypersons' guilt judgment accuracy was not influenced by the evidence presentation method used. Participants' accuracy rates were, however, above chance responding. Future research should examine whether law enforcement officers are better able to use the cues to deceit facilitated by SUE questioning in making accurate culpability judgments, as well as whether comprehensive SUE training increases SUE's usefulness in terms of aiding observers/investigators in making accurate judgments.

Concerning intellectual merit, this project contributed to the advancement of knowledge within the field of investigative interviewing. First, the interrogation paradigm developed and tested in Study 1 offers researchers a novel method of testing interviewing techniques in a controlled lab setting using samples that are more reflective of those encountered by law enforcement (as compared to typical paradigms that rely on student samples). Indeed, by using this paradigm, we were able to test interviewees' information management strategies in a psychologically-realistic context, using a diverse sample of participants. Second, our confession findings support the notion that guilt is one of the primary psychological drivers of making the decision to confess. Third, the present findings add to the ever-growing empirical research base that supports the benefits of science-based evidence presentation methods.

In regards to broader impacts, a central aim of the present research was to test an interrogation method that is grounded in psychological theory and offers a solution to customary practices that can increase the risk of false confession (and, thus, the risk of wrongful conviction). SUE methods have the potential to increase the usefulness of elicited information by providing investigators with a better way to discriminate between interviewees' trustworthy and deceptive statements. Furthermore, the methods used in this line of research, as well as the interrogation practices promoted via these findings, have the potential to encourage relationships between academics and practitioners (i.e., law enforcement). Indeed, our findings promote the value of SUE as a reliable method that can be included in science-based interviewing trainings, and that can ultimately aid investigators in the pursuit of their investigation goals. Lastly, the present research contributed to broadening the participation of underrepresented groups in science. A female doctoral student gained substantial experience in grant writing and management, as well as complex experimental design and implementation. The project also provided a large group of undergraduate research assistants (the majority from underrepresented groups in science; in particular, most identified as female and/or Hispanic/Latinx) with opportunities to participate in all stages of research.
